Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 41150 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
November 2010 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Asian Development Outlook 2011 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s members, 
Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADO  –  Asian Development Outlook 
  DER  –  Department of External Relations 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  ERMF  –  Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division 
  TA  –  technical assistance

Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability, promoting

Sustainable Development

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  As a flagship publication of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Asian Development 
Outlook (ADO) has become an important vehicle for enhancing ADB’s reputation as a credible 
and authoritative source of knowledge about the Asia and Pacific region. The report’s analysis 
of the region provides insights into appropriate policy responses for the economic issues the 
region faces. Its content informs ADB Management opinion and guides institutional views about 
the region’s macroeconomic prospects and important development issues. The production of 
the ADO has been regularly supported by technical assistance (TA) funding. The objectives, 
scope, and activities to be covered by the regional TA are in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The TA Strategic Forum 2008 recognized the important role that flagship publications 
such as the ADO play in monitoring the major economic issues and trends of ADB's developing 
member countries (DMCs). By regularly providing comprehensive analysis on the evolving 
developments in the DMCs, the ADO provides a basis for understanding the key drivers of, and 
constraints on, economic growth—a critical element for inclusiveness. In recent issues of the 
ADO,  the  publication  featured  timely  topics  on  rebalancing  growth,  macroeconomic 
management beyond the global financial crisis, and the key elements that will sustain Asia’s 
strong growth in the medium and long term. These are all important topics for developing Asia, 
especially in the aftermath of the global economic crisis.  
 
3.  To remain an independent and credible source of knowledge and information about the 
region, continuous work must be done to further enhance the quality of ADO analysis. Activities 
will include commissioning relevant applied and policy research on significant and contemporary 
macroeconomic issues at country and regional levels, developing new sources of information, 
and strengthening peer review. High-quality editing services are crucial to ensure that the 
ADO’s key messages are communicated clearly and effectively. To increase the ADO’s regional 
and  international  reach,  the  Economics  and  Research  Department  (ERD)  will  continue  to 
partner with the Department of External Relations (DER) to promote the ADO. 
 
4.  The ADO is one of the most frequently downloaded publications from ADB’s website.2 It 
is directly or indirectly the source of much international and national news commentary that 
features analysis, views, and opinions from ADB. Thus, a concerted effort, not just to come up 
with a high-quality publication but also to disseminate ADO content and policy messages, is vital 
to  elevate  the  publication’s  profile  and  to  ensure  its  relevance  and  usefulness  in  policy 
dialogues.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The TA will support activities that influence the intellectual environment within which 
authorities in developing Asia and the Pacific formulate economic policies, and at the same time 
promote ADB as an independent source of knowledge about the region. ADO 2011 and its 
                                                           
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 19 October 2010. 
2  In the last 5 years, the ADO and ADO Update have consistently ranked among the top ADB downloads from the 
month of launch until the following year. At the time of their launches, the ADO and ADO Update have continued to 
generate significant coverage from both global and regional top-tier media, such as the Financial Times, the Asian 
Wall Street Journal, and the International Herald Tribune.

2   
update will provide  in-depth, relevant, and timely assessment of the region’s economy. In 
addition, the reports will analyze important medium-term development issues relevant to DMC 
policy makers. Appendix 2 contains the draft contents pages of ADO 2011 and ADO 2011 
Update. The publication will be presenting original work on current and important issues of 
interest within developing Asia and the Pacific. 
 
6.  The TA will also further develop and refine analytical methods to support ADB’s short- 
and medium-term country economic monitoring and reporting. The methods will also strengthen 
the economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the DMCs covered, thereby 
enhancing ADB’s country assistance and promoting better-informed economic policies. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
7.  The main outputs of the TA will be the two publications: ADO 2011 and ADO 2011 
Update. The TA will support the following key activities: preparation of background analytical 
papers, further development and refinement of analytical methods, drafting of ADO content, 
economic  and  copy  editing,  preparation  and  layout  of  materials  for  publication,  and 
dissemination of key results and policy messages. The purpose of the background papers will 
be to provide a solid empirical and analytical foundation for ADO content. These papers will 
supplement  the  research  work  of  ADB’s  Macroeconomics  and  Finance  Research  Division 
(ERMF) on the selected topics, analyzing issues and policy implications for the DMCs covered 
using macroeconomic models, econometric analysis of data, and academic literature reviews. 
Some activities for the preparation of ADO 2012 will also be supported under the TA.  
  
8.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in approach across the different parts 
of the ADO, high-quality editing services are required. Economic and copy editing activities will 
be provided by  international consultants working under the direction of the assistant chief 
economist of ERMF.  
 
9.  Workshops and conferences will be organized as part of ADO preparation to strengthen 
the content. The writers’ workshop will focus on macroeconomic analysis of current issues, 
growth accounting, economic projections, and effective writing skills, which will target selected 
economists  in  regional  departments  and  national  officers  in  resident  missions  who  are 
responsible for writing the country chapters. One of the objectives of the workshop on effective 
writing is to equip writers with the skills and the tools needed to craft high-quality country 
chapters. This will also impart skills that are of broader relevance for economic and sector work, 
which underpins country strategies. The conferences will focus on the reports’ theme chapters. 
Distinguished  economists  from  the  region  will  be  invited  to  discuss  initial  drafts  of  the 
background papers to improve the analytical rigor and policy relevance of the theme chapters. 
 
10.  In collaboration with DER, the reports will be widely disseminated. The initial media 
launch will be followed by presentations cohosted by ADB development partners within and 
outside the Asia and Pacific region. Outreach will also include more analytical discussions of the 
issues in partnership with academic institutions and think tanks. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $690,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 3.

3 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will be the executing agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA. 
Given the high institutional profile of the ADO, the chief economist of ERD will report to the vice-
president for Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development, and the President at 
critical points in the reports’ preparation. The TA is expected to start in December 2010 and to 
be completed by March 2012. 
 
13.  The development of analytical tools and approaches to support high-quality ADO content 
will be a joint effort of ERMF economists, country economists of the regional departments and 
resident missions, national experts, international consultants, and economics editors. As in the 
previous years, ERMF will seek the cooperation of the regional departments to coordinate with 
the resident missions on the preparation of the country chapters.   
 
14.  The TA will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services, such as 
subscription to macroeconomic data providers (e.g., Bloomberg), as may be required to support 
relevant and up-to-date content. Equipment, such as computers and software, will be purchased 
by ADB in accordance with its Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) 
and  in  coordination  with  the  Office  of Information  Systems  and  Technology  and  Office of 
Administrative  Services,  where  applicable.  Equipment  will  be  turned  over  to  ADB  upon 
completion of the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with the ADB 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
15.  ADO workshops and conferences are tentatively scheduled for January, February, and 
July 2011 at ADB headquarters. The TA will cover the travel expenses of selected resident 
mission staff who will be participating in the workshops as resource persons. Contents of 
selected country chapters and other issues will also be discussed during the January workshop. 
Theme chapter background papers and other issues will be discussed during the February and 
July conferences. 
 
16.  The TA will require an estimated 18 person-months of international consultants’ time for 
economic and technical editing of ADO manuscripts before final publication of ADO 2011 and 
ADO 2011 Update. The ADO will also require 8 person-months of international consultancy 
resources for preparing background papers. Another 7 person-months of national economic 
consultants’ time will be required to assist in preparing country chapters and data sheets. The 
outline terms of reference for the consultants and resource persons are in Appendix 4. The 
consultants will be hired as individuals.3 Resource persons will also be engaged to act as 
discussants during the conferences. Consultants and resource persons will be engaged in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  
 
17.  The major results and key policy messages emerging from the ADO 2011 and ADO 
2011  Update  will  be  disseminated  to  the  media,  DMC  policy  makers,  and  academic 
communities. The media launch and subsequent roadshows will be undertaken by ERD in 
coordination with DER, while separate launches will be undertaken by resident missions in 
selected DMCs. Roundtable discussions and workshops in different academic and economic 
                                                           
3  The TA will involve independent studies and require rapid mobilization of the editorial consultants to ensure that 
there  are  no  delays  in  the  tight  production  schedule  of  the  publications.  In  addition,  the  experience  and 
qualifications of the individual consultants will be a primary consideration. Thus, the consultants will be hired on an 
individual basis.

4   
institutions  will  also  be  conducted  to  reach  a  wider  audience.  The  TA  will  support  the 
dissemination activities by ERD and DER. Both ADO 2011 and ADO 2011 Update will be 
featured on the ADB website, and printed copies will be distributed worldwide. The TA may 
support translation of the ADO into other languages, as may be required, to extend its audience 
in selected DMCs. This  will be arranged by regional departments in consultation with the 
resident missions concerned and DER.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $690,000 on a grant basis for 
the Asian Development Outlook 2011, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 4  11 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Economics Consultants (international, 8 person-months) 
1.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general macroeconomics 
and  a  good  knowledge  of  the  developing  member  country  economies.  Under  the  direct 
supervision of the relevant Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division (ERMF) staff, the 
consultants will 
(i)  prepare essays on current issues and country reports as may be assigned; 
(ii)  work with the economics editor to ensure consistency and coherence of the 
Asian Development Outlook (ADO); and 
(iii)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF. 
 
B.  Economics Editors (international, 12 person-months) 
 
2.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF and in consultation 
with other Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff in the Economics and Research Department 
involved in preparing and reviewing the country chapters or preparing the theme chapters for ADO 
2011 and ADO 2011 Update, the economics editors will edit the manuscripts for consistency and 
economic content. The editors will assist in preparing the highlights (English version) of the 
publication. The editors will also ensure that all the data in the publication are based on the most 
recent information available as of the specified cutoff date.  
 
3.  In particular, the economics editors will 
(i)  edit the ADO for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical evidence; 
(ii)  edit the manuscripts for internal consistency; 
(iii)  edit the reports for balanced coverage and degree of detail and precision; 
(iv)  check the reports for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to 
the prescribed requirements for the ADO; 
(v)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in 
the write-up; 
(vi)  confer with ERMF staff regarding gaps in the write-up, important questions, and 
needed revisions; 
(vii)  assist in preparing the publication highlights; 
(viii)  help prepare the key messages and review press releases for the ADO; and 
(ix)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF. 
 
C.  Manuscript Editor and Desktop Publishing Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
4.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF and in coordination 
with relevant ERMF staff, the specialist will (i) edit parts 1 and 3 of ADO 2011 and ADO 2011 
Update; (ii) copy edit all parts of the report in accordance with ADB’s editorial style; (iii) typeset 
and proofread the text, tables, and charts of the publication from the preliminary draft to the final 
copy and produce the high-resolution PDF files that will be sent to the external printer; (iv) be 
responsible for data linking to ensure data integrity and consistency in the final manuscript; and (v) 
convert the desktop files into PDF files for uploading to the ADB website. The specialist must have 
full working knowledge of Microsoft Office (Word and Excel) and publication software (Adobe 
InDesign and Illustrator).

Appendix 4  13 
 
7.  Resource persons (from both local institutions and offices of international organizations 
in the region) with knowledge of the theme chapter topics will also be engaged to act as 
discussants during the ADO theme conferences.  
 
E.  Economics Consultants (national, 7 person-months) 
 
8.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general economics. Under 
the  direct  supervision  of  relevant  ERMF  staff,  the  consultants  will  assist  in  the  economic 
research  work  of  the  ADB  Economics  and  Research  Department  and  undertake  general 
economic research. In particular, the consultants will 
(i)  conduct research  on  issues  related  to macroeconomic  development, growth, 
trade and investment, human capital development, and long-term employment 
generation in Asia and the Pacific; 
(ii)  support country economic analyses; 
(iii)  contribute to the preparation of the ADO and its update; 
(iv)  update the ADO data sheet; and 
(v)  undertake ad hoc research and other assignments as may be assigned by the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF.
